newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Cosatu union group slams S.African budget process.
newsitem.headline: Cosatu union group slams S.African budget process.

text.p: The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) on Thursday threatened to boycott all future parliamentary budget hearings unless its views were taken more seriously by government.

It also called for the dismissal of state expenditure director general Hannes Smit for allegedly saying that budget reform would take up to 15 years and that parliament would not be able to influence next year's budget.
Cosatu assistant secretary general Zwelinzima Vavi told the parliamentary finance committee that it was "toothless" and unable to make any changes to the budget.

He said that unless the committee piloted a bill through parliament this year that allowed it to make amendments to money bills such as the budget, "we will see no point in coming back...we can't participate in a process that is toothless just to give it credibility."

Cosatu has strongly condemned the 1997/98 budget for its emphasis on fiscal discipline and failure to reduce the tax burden on the poor. It argues it was based on the macroeconomic plan introduced last year, which it claimed catered mainly for the needs of private capital and foreign investors.
